Empires & Puzzles Khatrox 5 Star Legendary Nature Green from Forsaken Family Review

Khatrox is a slow-speed monster with a massive heal, a devastating hit-all, and a penchant for driving himself crazy. Is he the ultimate Rush Attack tank or just a liability? We dive into the madness of the Forsaken family.
Khatrox Review: The Blighted Bruiser Who Loves to Go Insane
Khatrox, The Blighted Bruiser: Insanity, Healing, and Obliteration

Khatrox is a Legendary Nature hero from the Forsaken family, released in September 2025 as part of the Shadow Summon event. He arrives on the scene with a toolkit that screams "go big or go home." As a Slow mana hero, he fits the classic mold of a tank or Rush Attack specialist, but with a Lovecraftian twist: Insanity. He heals your team for a massive amount, hits the enemy team like a truck, and then inflicts madness upon everyoneâ€”including himself. He is not for the faint of heart or those who prefer safe, predictable battles.

Khatrox's design is delightfully grotesque, leaning heavily into the "Eldritch horror" theme of the Shadow/Forsaken families. He looks like a Cthulhu-inspired linebacker who has spent too much time at an all-you-can-eat buffet in the sunken city of R'lyeh. The glowing green runes on his belly and the singular, unblinking eye give him a menacing presence. It is a fantastic creature design that stands out against the more traditional knights and elves of the game. You probably wouldn't want to hug him, though.

Khatrox boasts stats that are very much in line with the high power creep of late 2025. With a base Power of 1235 and an Attack stat over 1300, he is a heavy hitter. His Health pool sits comfortably at 2263, which is excellent for a tank.
When we compare him to the very latest heroes from December 2025 (like Adelitza with ~1264 Power), Khatrox is still extremely competitive. He hasn't lost any shine in the few months since his release; he is a stat monster.
This skill is a roller coaster. Let's break it down:
1000 HP is a huge chunk of health, often fully healing damaged allies or providing a massive overheal buffer.
enemies is significant, even at Slow speed. It's enough to wipe softened teams or severely cripple fresh ones.
He gives 20 Insanity to all enemies, which acts as a disruption mechanic, potentially causing them to falter later. However, he gives

The stored damage mechanic (up to 1000 returned to enemies) is a nice deterrent against being sniped immediately after firing, but since he just healed himself for 1000, he's likely at full health anyway.

The 50 self-Insanity is the elephant in the room. It puts him halfway to the "Mindless" state immediately. If he fires twice, he hits 100 Insanity, which can make him a liability if you don't have a way to manage it or if the battle drags on.

Slow speed requires 12 tiles. With a level 29 Magic/Styx troop or level 30 Legendary troop and his family bonus (if active), you can shave this down, but he will primarily shine in Rush Attack or with mana boosters.
With ~1312 Attack, a 470% hit deals roughly
raw damage value before defense reduction. Spread across 5 enemies, that is a total output of
raw damage. This is top-tier AoE damage.
A flat 1000 Boosted Health to 5 allies is
total health added to your board state. This is one of the highest raw healing numbers in the game.

The 20 Insanity on enemies is a slow burn. It reduces their effectiveness slightly and prepares them for a potential mental break, but don't count on it to shut them down immediately. The 50 Insanity on self means he has a "soft cap" on how many times he can fire without risking self-sabotage.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities

The Forsaken family bonus provides Critical Chance and Healing bonuses. For a hero like Khatrox who already boosts health by 1000, the healing bonus makes him even harder to kill. The critical chance helps his tile damage, which is already high due to his Barbarian class and high attack stat.
This is his insurance policy. If he dies, he has a chance to be reborn as an Eldritch Host. The chance scales with his Insanity (5% per 10 Insanity).
If he fires once (50 Insanity), he has a
If he is nearing full madness (100 Insanity), he has a

to revive.
The Host form has solid stats (1000 Atk/Def) and full inherited health, meaning you essentially have to kill him twice. It's a high-RNG mechanic that can swing a match or do absolutely nothing.
is a defensive power that reduces special skill damage received. This fits his role perfectly, helping him survive long enough to charge his slow mana.
Released in the "Shadow" era of late 2025, Khatrox represents the shift towards complex mechanics (Insanity) coupled with raw power (high stats). He was designed to be a Rush Attack dominator.
His stats are modern. His 470% AoE hit is higher than many older Slow heroes (like Colen or Isarnia) by a massive margin, and he heals on top of it. He outclasses almost every Season 1-4 Slow hero.

but niche. In Rush Attack wars and tournaments, he is an absolute terror. Outside of Very Fast modes, he is risky due to Slow speed and the self-Insanity. He is not a "put in every team" hero, but a specialized nuke.
Maximizes his survivability, ensuring he lives to fire his Slow skill. Synergizes with his role as a tank or flank.
Lowers his kill potential slightly on the special skill and bleed damage.
Pushes his already high attack stat further, making his 470% hit absolutely lethal. Increases bleed damage from Barbarian talents.
Makes him slightly squishier, which is risky for a Slow hero.
path is recommended. His job is to fire
. If he fires, the 1000 HP heal and massive damage swing the battle. You need to ensure he survives to that point.
A 1000 HP heal AND a 470% AoE hit in one skill is incredible value.
In Very Fast modes, he is arguably one of the best centers in the game.
High base stats, Boosted Health, and the stored damage mechanic make him hard to take down.
The passive gives him a second wind, which can be annoying for attackers.
Without Rush rules or mana troops, he can be killed before he does anything.
He hurts his own mental stability. Firing him repeatedly becomes dangerous as he approaches 100 Insanity.
You cannot rely on the revive; 25-50% is a coin flip at best.
While the text says the stored damage return is undispellable, usually the
storing it can be prevented or the hero killed before it triggers (though he likely just healed).
This is his playground. He is S-Tier here.
His massive heal and damage make him great for clearing waves and surviving hard bosses, provided you bring mana potions.
The boosted health is invaluable for countering permanent damage (curses), though his slow speed is a drag.
A nightmare to kill. Revivers on wings, Khatrox in the middle to heal everyone and nuke the enemy.
While risky, stacking Insanity heroes can overwhelm the enemy with mental status effects while Khatrox keeps the team alive.
Hel, Proteus, or anyone who stops mana generation shuts him down completely.
Miki or Peters can prevent him from casting his devastating skill.
Avoid pairing him with other heroes who
give self-insanity unless you have a specific plan, as your whole team might go crazy.

If you pull Khatrox early, he will carry you through the map stages easily. His heal alone makes your team immortal in Season 1 and 2. Focus on keeping him alive with potions. In raids, he might be too slow without high-level troops, so use him defensively.

He is a luxury tool for Rush Attack. If you care about maintaining a top-tier Rush defense, he is worth the mats. However, if you already have stellar Green tanks (like a toon-costume Kadilen or similar), he might be redundant. Do not LB2 him unless you plan to use him as your primary tank.
The community reaction to Khatrox was mixed, bordering on confused.
One player noted on the forums:
"This is a damn good hero. Then we look at the current meta. Excellent hero."
citing his ability to flip a match.
However, others were skeptical about the Insanity trade-off:
"It should be 100% insanity on the caster because you're giving 45 insanity after a while to others, but you're keeping the caster safe. Scrap."
(Referring to a different hero in the batch, but the sentiment on Insanity mechanics being "balanced" via self-harm was common).
A common complaint was the RNG of the passive:
"The chance to be reborn as eldritch host is far too low... Overall, quite disappointing for such a brand new hero from a premium portal."
Beta feedback highlighted that while his stats are "nasty," the slow speed is a significant hurdle outside of Rush modes.

Khatrox is the definition of a "high risk, high reward" hero, packaged in a slime-covered, tentacled wrapper. When he works, he obliterates the enemy team and heals yours to full. When he fails, he dies with a full mana bar or goes insane and hits his own allies. He brings a chaotic energy to Empires & Puzzles that is both frustrating and fun.
A monster in Rush Attack, a solid tank option, but perhaps too unstable for general offense.
Disclaimer: No Old Ones were summoned during the writing of this review, though we did feel a bit insane calculating those stats.
